F1_technology.name: AI & Technology
key_data: AI VC funding = 50% of all global VC ($192.7B through Oct 2025)
Enterprise AI revenue: $37B in 2025 (3x YoY)
Application spend ($19B) now exceeds infrastructure spend ($18B)
85% of AI startups expected out of business within 3 years
Perez cycle: late Installation, approaching Turning Point
AI coding: 25-40% of Google code AI-generated
Manufacturing AI gap: 98% exploring, 20% ready (78-point gap)
FDA AI/ML devices: 1,250+ cumulative, 295 in 2025
F1_technology.2031_projection: Early Deployment phase — AI shifts from infrastructure build to systematic economic integration

F2_demographics.name: Demographics
key_data: Japan: -900K population/yr, 397 robots per 10K workers (world #1)
China: fertility ~1.0 (below Japan 1.20), population halves to 633M by 2100
US: native-born working-age population shrinking, immigration = 100% of growth
EU: losing ~1M workers/yr, 22 of 27 countries declining
India: 1.44B population, median age 28, adding 183M working-age people by 2050
Africa: 830M youth aged 15-35 by 2050
Pipeline collapse: CPA -33%, nursing 78K->200K, teaching 42 states, trucking age 57
F2_demographics.2031_projection: World splits into shrinking (Japan/China/EU), peak dividend (India/SEA), and pre-dividend (Africa) labor regimes

F3_geopolitics.name: Geopolitics
key_data: US chip export controls: 4th major revision, 120+ Chinese entities restricted
China: 35% semiconductor equipment self-sufficiency, 15% global AI model share
EU AI Act: high-risk obligations effective Aug 2026, penalties up to 7% global turnover
DeepSeek R1: 3%->13% global LLM share in 2 months, approaching frontier performance
Gulf AI pivot: Saudi Humain $77B + UAE MGX $25B — third AI capital center forming
Global defense spending $2.72T (+9.4%); NATO target raised to 5% GDP by 2035
CHIPS Act fabs in production: Intel 1.8nm HVM, TSMC Arizona volume, Samsung Taylor 90%+
Kearney Reshoring Index -311: intention vs execution gap persists
F3_geopolitics.2031_projection: Three distinct AI regulatory/technology blocs — US-led, China-led, EU-regulated — with India and MENA as swing players

F4_capital.name: Capital Flows
F4_capital.key_metric: $500B+ AI spend vs 56% seeing no benefit
key_data: Fed funds rate: 3.50-3.75% (Jan 2026)
68% of CEOs increasing AI spend despite 56% reporting zero financial benefit
Only 12% of companies achieved both cost and revenue gains from AI
PE refinancing wall: $936B-$1.8T debt maturing 2026-2028, distress rate 11.98% (+148%)
VC AI share: 35-40% of ~$500B global VC
Physical production ETFs: Industrials +15.1%, Materials +20.1%
CRE vacancy: Office 20.1% (record), $929B CRE debt maturing
Kearney Reshoring Index fell 311 points — intention vs execution gap
95% of manufacturers plan new automation within 3 years
F4_capital.2031_projection: Capital rotation from pure-digital to hard-tech/physical accelerates through Perez Turning Point correction

F5_psychology.name: Psychology & Fear
key_data: AI adoption plateau: 46% for 12 months (flat) — psychological ceiling, not technology ceiling
US AI trust: 32% (lowest major economy) vs China: 87%
Healthcare trust gap: 34 points (providers 7/10 vs patients 3.6/10)
Fear economy TAM: ~$86B by 2030 (governance $15.8B + safety $9.8B + cybersecurity $60.6B)
Only 2% of executives made layoffs from actual AI implementation — rest anticipatory
86% of consumers say human interaction important in brand experience
Generational divide: Gen Z 67% excited vs Boomers 29% excited / 51% worried
96% of music professionals open to paying more for human-created content
F5_psychology.2031_projection: Fear normalizes but creates permanent parallel economy — human premium, verification, trust-bridging services

F6_energy.name: Energy & Resources
F6_energy.key_metric: Data centers: 4%+ of US electricity today
key_data: US data center electricity: 4%+ of total today, projected 6-12% by 2030
Grid bottleneck: 2,600 GW in interconnection queue, 5+ year wait — THE binding constraint on AI scaling
Nuclear renaissance: 10GW+ committed for AI (TMI restart, Kairos SMR, Talen)
Solar LCOE: $0.02-0.03/kWh best locations (all-time low)
Global battery storage: 120 GWh installed (2025), doubling annually
China controls 60-90% of rare earth processing
Copper structural deficit: $9,500/ton, new mines take 15-20 years
Renewable investment: $1.1T globally — first time exceeding fossil fuel investment
F6_energy.2031_projection: Energy becomes THE gatekeeper of AI deployment — winners defined by power access, nuclear restarts, and mineral supply chains

us.name: United States
us.2031_outlook: Fastest AI adoption in services, reshoring dependent on automation, financial services cascade creates mass restructuring

china.2031_outlook: Automation adoption among world's highest from demographic necessity, parallel tech stack matures, worker-to-retiree ratio hits 4:1

eu.name: European Union
eu.2031_outlook: Slower AI adoption vs US/China but deeper regulatory framework exports globally, defense-tech surge

japan.name: Japan
japan.2031_outlook: Template for every aging economy — solutions that work in Japan export to US/EU within 5-15 years

india.name: India
top_forces: 70% youth skills gap = massive reskilling opportunity
india.2031_outlook: World's largest supplier of new workers, AI augmentation (not replacement) model, education-tech epicenter

latam.name: Latin America
latam.2031_outlook: Nearshoring-driven manufacturing growth, Brazil as regional AI leader, Argentina reform experiment

mena.name: Middle East & North Africa
top_forces: SWFs becoming top-5 global AI capital allocators
Economic diversification from oil driving AI investment
mena.2031_outlook: Third global AI capital center alongside US and China, massive infrastructure buildout, alternative funding source for physical production

africa.name: Africa
top_forces: Only continent with explosive working-age growth
africa.2031_outlook: Largest untapped market for AI-native services, mobile-first model, constrained by connectivity and digital skills

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: 34-point trust gap: providers 7/10 vs patients 3.6/10. Patient trust, opacity, liability, clinical vs admin split
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: Admin/back-office AI normalized, clinical AI still contested

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: Billable-hour conflict, 700+ AI hallucination court cases, liability
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: AI-augmented practice standard, human judgment premium remains

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: Academic integrity, cultural values, faculty resistance
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: AI tools ubiquitous, human teaching premium emerges

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: 73% adoption rate — LOWEST fear friction, control group. Regulatory caution, governance gaps, explainability

fear_friction_index.2031_projection: 95% plan automation by 2028, robotics standard in new facilities

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: Business model conflict, expertise identity, client trust
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: Barbell: routine cognitive eliminated, judgment premium rises

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: Identity/authenticity crisis, union action, human premium demand
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: Parallel artisan economy, verification infrastructure, premium human content

fear_friction_index.primary_drivers: 80% automation risk in call centers, but 86% want human interaction
fear_friction_index.2031_projection: Automated base layer, human premium tier, loyalty-driven differentiation

key_findings.title: Fear Is a Market, Not Just Sentiment
key_findings.detail: Fear-driven markets (safety, compliance, governance, ethics, insurance, verification) total ~$86B by 2030 (governance $15.8B + safety $9.8B + cybersecurity $60.6B). AI Ethics Consulting alone at 45.9% CAGR. Fear of AI is itself a massive economic force creating entirely new industry categories.

key_findings.title: The Great Anticipatory Overshoot
key_findings.detail: Only 2% of executives report making large layoffs from actual AI implementation. The vast majority are anticipatory — based on AI's potential, not performance. This creates psychological overshoot: more fear, displacement, and safety demand than actual technology warranted. Correction likely by 2028-2029.

key_findings.title: Three Demographic Regimes Diverge
key_findings.detail: Shrinking labor force (Japan -900K/yr, China fertility ~1.0, EU -1M/yr, US native-born declining) creates automation pull. Peak dividend (India 1.44B population, median age 28, adding 183M workers) creates skills opportunity. Pre-dividend (Africa 830M youth by 2050) creates future market. Same technology, completely different adoption paths.

key_findings.title: Perez Turning Point Approaching
key_findings.detail: AI startup failure: 85% expected out within 3 years. Application spend now exceeds infrastructure spend. $500B/yr invested but 56% of CEOs see no benefit. These are classic late-Installation Frenzy signals. Correction before Deployment phase when structural forces create maximum leverage.

key_findings.title: Human Premium Is Durable
key_findings.detail: 96% of music professionals open to paying more for human-created. 86% of consumers want human interaction. Up to 16% willingness to pay more for human service. Blockchain verification targeting mainstream by mid-2026. Not replacing AI — creating parallel artisan economy like organic food movement.

key_findings.title: Energy Is the Gatekeeper
key_findings.magnitude: Data centers: 4%+ of US electricity today
key_findings.detail: AI compute demand outpacing energy supply. Data centers already consuming 4%+ of US electricity, projected 6-12% by 2030. Grid bottleneck: 2,600 GW in interconnection queue with 5+ year wait. Hyperscalers restarting nuclear (Three Mile Island), building SMRs. Nuclear renaissance: 10GW+ committed. Solar at all-time low LCOE ($0.02-0.03/kWh). Winners defined by power access. Creates new Ricardian rent around power-advantaged locations.

key_findings.title: Three AI Blocs Are Forming
key_findings.detail: US-led (innovation-first, state-level patchwork), China-led (state-controlled, content-aligned), EU-regulated (comprehensive risk-based, extraterritorial). India and MENA are swing players. Cross-bloc compliance becomes its own business category. Each bloc develops distinct tech stacks.

key_findings.title: Reskilling Chasm Is the Central Policy Challenge
key_findings.detail: 170M new jobs created but 92M displaced by 2030 (WEF). 39% of current skills will be obsolete. 59% of workers won't receive adequate training. Entry-level workers aged 22-25 already seeing 13% employment decline in AI-exposed occupations. Alternative credentials surging: certificates +28%.

key_findings.title: Financial Services Enters Acceleration Phase
key_findings.magnitude: First sector to cross phase threshold
key_findings.detail: Financial services is the first sector to enter the acceleration phase of AI transformation. 54% of customer interactions already automated, 87% AI fraud detection at 92% interception rate. 73% adoption rate with lowest fear friction of any sector — the control group showing what adoption looks like without psychological barriers. 339 branch closures. CPA pipeline -33%. PE refinancing wall ($936B-$1.8T) creates distressed acquisition catalyst.

key_findings.title: AI Adoption Plateau at 46%
key_findings.magnitude: Stalled for 12 months despite capability improvements
key_findings.detail: AI adoption has plateaued at 46% for 12 months — an unprecedented S-curve flattening. This is a psychological ceiling, not a technology ceiling. Capability improvements have not translated into adoption increases. The gap between what AI can do and what organizations will adopt is widening. Financial services (73% adoption) proves the technology works; psychology determines the speed. Breaking this plateau requires trust-building, not better models.

new_sectors_this_cycle.note: v2 had ZERO defense models — $2.72T global spend
55% discomfort, Baumol stored energy, reskilling chasm
Grid bottleneck = binding constraint on AI scaling
Gulf AI pivot, India dividend, EU AI Act, Japan aging
Micro-firm OS, human premium, cascade services

model_inventory.note: Central output of the engine: business models rated through 5-axis system with economy map as grading context
confirmed_cascades: Financial services: BLS -49K, financials ETF last (+0.5%), delinquency 1.78%

cycle_history.note: PIVOT: Economy mapping. 6 forces, 8 regions, fear friction, demographics, geopolitics.
First institutional-grade cycle: 5-axis rating, 15 model cards, 5 sector briefs, 4 geographic reports, 84 signals graded.

PIVOT BACK: Models as central output. 235 v2 models individually migrated through 5-axis rating, 287 algorithmically estimated, 45 NEW models from macro gaps (defense, education, fear, energy, geo, emerging). Economy map is grading context, not standalone output.
